case_name: Trustees of the Port of Madras v. Steamer Agents

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 187 to 191 of 1962 filed by Trustees of Port of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 187 to 191 of 1962. Appeals from the judgment and order dated March 3 1961

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated March 3 1961 of Madras High Court in Writ Appeal Nos. 53 to 57 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated March 3 1961 of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal Nos. 53, 54, 55, 56, and 57 of 1960, C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 11, 1962 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. December 11. The judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-The appellants, the Trustees of the Port of Madras, hereinafter called the Board,

facts.text: Appellants are Trustees of Port of Madras, called the Board.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, the Trustees of the Port of Madras, hereinafter called the Board, appeal against the order of the High Court of Madras allowing the writ petitions

facts.text: Respondents are partnership firms or limited companies carrying on business of steamer agents at Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, who are either partnership firms or limited companies, carry on the business of steamer agents at Madras.

facts.text: Madras High Court allowed writ petitions under Art. 226 filed by respondents and issued writ of mandamus directing Board to forbear from enforcing scale E rates and requiring signing of Shore Labour Requisition Form.

anchor.surface_text: appeal against the order of the High Court of Madras allowing the writ petitions filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution by each of the respondents and issuing a writ of mandamus directing the appellants to forbear from enforcing the scale E rates

facts.text: Board made amendments to Madras Port Trust Scale of Rates in 1958 with sanction of Central Government, adding scale E under Chapter V effective March 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Board, with the sanction of the Central Government, made amendments to the Madras Port Trust Scale of Rates in 1958. By the amendment, scale E was added under Chapter V. It was to come into force from March 1, 1958.

facts.text: Scale E lays down charges payable by masters, owners or agents of vessels for Port Trust labour requisitioned and supplied but not fully or properly utilised due to lapse on part of ship owners or extra payment for simultaneous working at multiple hatches.

anchor.surface_text: The scale laid down charges to be paid by masters, owners or agents of vessels in respect of Port Trust labour requisitioned and supplied but not fully or properly utilised. The charges, for the sake of brevity, may be said to be on account of the labour of the Port Trust,

facts.text: Labour requisition form modified to contain undertaking by steamer-agents to pay charges in scale of rates for idle labour or not properly utilised and for working more than one hook simultaneously.

anchor.surface_text: The labour requisition Form to be submitted by the steamer-agents was also modified and the new form contained an undertaking on the part of the steamer-agents for the payment of the charges laid down in the Boards scale of rates from time to time in respect of labour rendered idle or not properly utilised

facts.text: Amendments made by Board under section 42 of Madras Port Trust Act, 1905.

anchor.surface_text: These amendments in the scale of rates were made by the Board in the exercise of its power under s. 42 of the Madras Port Trust Act, 1905 (Mad. Act II of 1905), hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Respondents filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in Madras High Court praying for mandamus directing Board not to enforce scale E rates and not to require new form.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondents, viz., the steamer-agents, filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution, in the High Court of Madras, and prayed for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing the Board not to enforce these rates and not to require the filling in of the new form.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge of High Court dismissed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions were disposed of by a learned Single judge of the High Court. He dismissed them holding that the liability to pay the charges.- being for services rendered,

facts.text: Appellate Bench of High Court reversed Single Judge, allowed writ petitions and issued writ of mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the appellate Bench reversed the order, allowed the petitions and issued a writ of mandamus as prayed. It held that the Board had no authority to introduce the new scale E rates payable by the master, owner or agent of the vessel,

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeals, set aside High Court order, dismissed writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeals with costs here and in the Courts below, set aside the order of the Court below and dismiss the writ petitions.

facts.text: Prior to March 1, 1958, cost of shore-labour met entirely by Port Trust, no distinction for idle time.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to March 1, 1958 the cost of shore- labour was met entirely by the Port Trust. No distinction was made between the charges for shore labour in ordinary cases and charges for shore- labour in respect of idle, time or additional work.

facts.text: Board adopted piece-rate scheme for Dock workers pursuant to Jeejeebhoy Committee report, scale E part of scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The Board adopted the piece-rate scheme for the Dock workers in pursuance of the report of the jeejeebhoy Committee and the new scale E rates are a part of such a scheme.

facts.text: Under revised procedure from August 1, 1957, steamer agent required to make application and deposit before ship reaches berth for overtime, cranes, etc., and from March 1, 1958 for scale E.

anchor.surface_text: Under the revised procedure adopted by the Board on August 1, 1957, before a ship has reached its berth, the steamer agent is required to make an application and a deposit in his current account to cover charges for the working of the vessel in respect of overtime,

facts.text: Circular Exhibit-B issued by Board on February 25, 1958 to steamer agents explaining Piece-Rate Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: A circular Exhibit-B was issued by the Board to all the steamer agents on February 25, 1958, explaining the features of the Piece-Rate Scheme for Dock and Stevedore works for the Port of Madras.

facts.text: Board admitted direct arrangements between ship-owner, master or agent with stevedores but did not accept allegations about nature of rates and legal position.

anchor.surface_text: The Board, by the common counter-affidavit filed on its behalf by the Deputy Traffic Manager of the Madras Port Trust, admitted the direct arrangements between the ship-owner, master, or agent with the stevedores but did not accept the allegations about the nature of the various rates

facts.text: Steamer agents inform Traffic Manager probable date of vessel arrival, tonnage hatch-wise, number of hatches proposed.

anchor.surface_text: usually, the steamer agent informs the Traffic Manager the probable date of arrival of the vessel under his agency, tonnage hatch-wise of cargo to be landed at Madras and the number of hatches proposed to be worked.

facts.text: After cargo hoisted to quayside, shore labour unsling cargo, Trust's Tally Clerk notes items, duplicate copy of import tally sheet given to steamer agent's representative as receipt under s.39(3).

anchor.surface_text: When the sling rests on the shore or in the barge in the case of discharge at moorings, the shore labour unsling the cargo and the Trusts Tally Clerk notes the items in a tally sheet. As each sheet is closed a duplicate copy of the import tally sheet is given to the steamer agents representative on the spot. This duplicate copy is the receipt prescribed under section 39 (3) of the Madras Port Trust Act

facts.text: Consignee obtains delivery order from steamer agent, files Harbour Import Application with Trust and Bill of Entry with Customs, pays duty and harbour dues, then receives cargo.

anchor.surface_text: The consignee obtains delivery order from the Steamer agent and then files Harbour Import Application with the Trust for payment of Harbour dues and Bill of Entry with the Customs for the duty payable by him. On payment of the duty and the harbour dues by the consignee the cargo is delivered to him by the Trust.

issues.text: whether the law making the steamer-agent liable to pay these charges is good law

anchor.surface_text: The question for determination, in the case, then is whether the law making the steamer-agent liable to pay these charges is good law.

issues.text: the legal obligation of the master in respect of the unloading of the cargo
whether the Board takes charge of the goods on behalf of the ship-owner or on behalf of the consignee
whether the charges for labour rendered idle are in the nature of compensation or damages in respect of any loss, inconvenience or expenses caused to the Board
whether the services under section 39 are services to the ship-owner or to the consignee

anchor.surface_text: whatever services it performs at the time of the landing of the goods or on their removal thereafter, are services rendered to the ship.

issues.text: whether the Board is a bailee of the ship-owner under sections 151, 152 and 161 of the Indian Contract Act

anchor.surface_text: when the Board takes charge of the goods from the ship-owner, the ship-owner is the bailor and the Board is the bailee, and the Boards responsibility for the goods thereafter is that of a bailee.

arguments.claim: ship-owners and steamer-agents cannot be made liable for charges for shore labour employed in the receiving or removal of cargo and such charges must be borne by the consignee

anchor.surface_text: They contended that  1  the ship-owners and the steamer-agents cannot be made liable for charges for shore labour employed in the receiving or removal of cargo and such charges must be borne by the consignee  II  s. 39 of the Act provided for -the performance of services by the Board

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e goods. The provision of there being a lien on the goods for the payment of the dues of the Board or the freight, make it clear that the Board did nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Services under s.39 are to ship-owner, Board bailee of ship-owner

arguments.claim: s. 39 of the Act provided for the performance of services by the Board and the other sections provided for the imposition and recovery of rates for the services performed for the vessel and services performed for the goods. Services in the former category are to be paid for on behalf of the carrier i.e., by the master, ship-owner or the steamer-agent, and the services in the latter category constitute a liability on the consignee

anchor.surface_text: II  s. 39 of the Act provided for -the performance of services by the Board and the other sections provided for the imposition and recovery of rates for the services performed for the vessel and services performed for the goods. arguments.court_reasoning: Board performs services to ship if required by owner (incl agent), charges under s42 valid

arguments.claim: the Board has power to impose and recover rates only for services rendered and that they have no right to impose charges by way of compensation for default or to collect charges from masters, owners or agents of vessels in respect of operations not properly falling under the head of discharge of cargo from the vessel

anchor.surface_text: iii  the Board has power to impose and recover rates only for services rendered and that they have no right to impose charges by way of compensation for default or to collect charges from masters, owners or agents of vessels in respect of operations not properly falling under the head of discharge of cargo from the vessel

arguments.court_reasoning: Charges are for services/facilities under s42, not damages

arguments.claim: prior to 1914, the steamer-agents acted as landing-agents for removing cargo from ship to pier and collected for these services from the consignees a separate charge known as landing charge in addition to the freight. When the quays were constructed and cargo came to be landed there, the Board took over the landing of goods and collected quay dues instead of landing charges which were wholly paid by the consignees. These quay dues later on merged in the harbour dues collected by the Board from the consignees

anchor.surface_text: iv  prior to 1914, the steamer-agents acted as landing-agents for removing cargo from ship to pier and collected for these services from the consignees a separate charge known as landing charge in addition to the freight. When the quays were constructed and cargo came to be landed there, the Board took over the landing of goods and collected quay dues instead of landing charges which were wholly paid by I he consignees. These quay dues later on merged in the harbour dues collected by the Board from the consignees

arguments.claim: the compulsion imposed on steamer agents in the matter of payment of the scale E rates and in respect of the signing of the requisition for shore labour is outside the authority conferred by law on the trustees of the Port of Madras and is illegal. Such an imposition whether as charges for services or as compensation for default of steamer agents is illegal and an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right of the petitioners to carry on business as steamer agents and is inoperative in law

anchor.surface_text: The compulsion imposed on steamer agents in the matter of payment of the scale E rates and in respect of the signing of the requisition for shore labour is outside the authority conferred by law on the trustees of the Port of Madras and is illegal. Such an imposition whether as charges for services or as compensation for default of steamer agents is illegal and an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right of the petitioners to carry on business as steamer agents and is inoperative in law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Scale E sanctioned under s42,44 has force of law, good law

arguments.claim: the Port Trust authorities receiving goods on the quay or in the barge at moorings, do so on behalf of the consignee

anchor.surface_text: xi  the Port Trust authorities receiving goods on the quay or in the barge at moorings, do so on behalf of the consignee.

arguments.court_reasoning: Receiving on behalf of ship-owner, Board bailee of ship-owner

arguments.claim: the Harbour dues on the import cargo under scale A, Chapter II of the Scale of Rates, are payable on tonnage and include, beside overhead, a nominal rent for storage for a specified period etc., and the item of charges for porterage involved in moving the goods from the landing point to the storage or stacking point

anchor.surface_text: The Board, by the common counter-affidavit filed on its behalf by the Deputy Traffic Manager of the Madras Port Trust, admitted the direct arrangements between the ship-owner, master, or agent with the stevedores but did not accept the allegations about the nature of the various rates and duties levied and the legal position as stated in the petitions. According to the Board,  i  the Harbour dues on the import cargo under scale A, Chapter II of the Scale of Rates, are payable on tonnage and include, beside overhead, a nominal rent for storage for a specified period etc., and the item of charges for porterage involved in moving the goods from the landing point to the storage or stacking point.

arguments.claim: It is not correct that the ship-owner has nothing to do with the import cargo after it has been landed by the stevedores at the landing point on the quay, as the ship-owner in each case by the bill of lading has to deliver the goods to the consignee named in the bill of lading or his nominee and he remains liable under his contract until he has delivered the goods to the person who is entitled to take delivery of the goods

anchor.surface_text: ii  It is not correct that the ship-owner has nothing to do with the import cargo after it has been landed by the stevedores at the landing point on the quay, as the ship-owner in each case by the bill of lading has to deliver the goods to the consignee named in the bill of lading or his nominee and he remains liable under his contract until he has delivered the goods to the person who is entitled to take delivery of the goods.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: at as between the master of the ship and the companysignee, the Act made it obligatory that the companysignee gets his goods from the Board and number

arguments.court_reasoning: Carrier responsibility continues till delivery to entitled person

arguments.claim: Under s. 39 of the Act the Port Trust gives facilities and undertakes certain services. One of such services is the moving of the goods from the landing point to the storage or stacking point and thereafter delivering the goods to the persons entitled under the bill of lading. The Board does not undertake the unloading of the goods from the ship to the quay. The ship-owner makes his own arrangements through the stevedores... It is a service to the ship-owner by the Board to give the ship-owner a receipt for the goods to keep them in custody and deliver to the consignee. The services undertaken in respect of the import cargo till they have been moved to the storage or stacking point are services to the ship-owner for which the ship-owner or master or steamer agent is primarily liable and the charges may properly and legally be levied from them

anchor.surface_text: iii  Under s. 39 of the Act the Port Trust gives facilities and undertakes certain services. One of such services is the moving of the goods from the landing point to the storage or stacking point and thereafter delivering the goods to the persons entitled under the bill of lading. The Board does not undertake the unloading of the goods from the ship to the quay. The ship-owner makes his own arrangements through the stevedores, though the Board is authorised to undertake such services on behalf of the ship-owner. It is a service to the ship-owner by the Board to give the ship-owner a receipt for the goods to keep them in custody and deliver to the consignee. The services undertaken in respect of the import cargo till they have been moved to the storage or stacking point are services to the ship-owner for which the ship-owner or master or steamer agent is primarily liable and the charges may properly and legally be levied from them.

arguments.claim: The Board collects the harbour dues from the consignee at the time of giving delivery, but in fact makes that collection as agent of the ship-owner, master, steamer agent who are primarily the persons liable for the dues

anchor.surface_text: iv  The Board collects the harbour dues from the consignee at the time of giving delivery, but in fact makes that collection as agent of the ship-owner, master, steamer agent who are primarily the persons liable for the dues.

arguments.claim: The issuance of a receipt to the master at the landing point is a mere matter of convenience for betokening the fact that the goods have been handed over to the Port Trust for removal, storage and delivery and does not in any way detract from the fact that the subsequent services are facilities and services rendered to the ship-owner in respect of the goods which are the subject of contract of carriage by the ship-owner

anchor.surface_text: vi  The issuance of a receipt to the master at the landing point is a mere matter of convenience for betokening the fact that the goods have been handed over to the Port Trust for removal, storage and delivery and does not in any way detract from the fact that the subsequent services are facilities and services rendered to the ship-owner in respect of the goods which are the subject of contract of carriage by the ship-owner.

arguments.court_reasoning: Receipt under s39(3), services to ship-owner

arguments.claim: The past practice had been for the agents to inform the Board about the shore labour which would be necessary... The proper utilisation of the time of the labour depends upon the steamer agents...

anchor.surface_text: vii  The past practice had been for the agents to inform the Board about the shore labour which would be necessary for moving the goods in respect of each steamer. Prior to 1956, this was done orally and then the Form was introduced which contains the same particulars except the undertaking to pay the scale E charges as the impugned Form contains. Since the enforcement of the new piece-rate scheme, the payment to labour was not based on tonnage but a daily wage was fixed along with a provision for payment for idle time and hook allowance...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s of the Piece-Rate Scheme for Dock and Stevedore works for the Port of Madras. The Board emphasized that the Piece- Rate Scheme was formulated to inc

arguments.court_reasoning: Piece-rate scheme valid, scale E part

arguments.claim: The levy of multiple hook allowance against the steamer agents is a facility to the ship to discharge fast and sail quicker... As working of additional hooks in a vessels hatch benefits the ship, the recovery of hook allowance from the steamer agents under scale E is legitimate

anchor.surface_text: ix  The levy of multiple hook allowance against the steamer agents is a facility to the ship to discharge fast and sail quicker. When two or more hooks work in a ships hatch, the gangs handling cargo will not be in a position to handle more cargo and therefore the approval of Board was obtained for payment of an allowance to compensate such loss in their earnings. As working of additional hooks in a vessels hatch benefits the ship, the recovery of hook allowance from the steamer agents under scale E is legitimate.

arguments.claim: The additional charge made under scale E is a charge in respect of facilities afforded to and services undertaken on behalf of the ship-owner, master, agent by the Board in relation to the cargo which is under contract of carriage by them, in the same way as harbour dues

anchor.surface_text: x  The additional charge made under scale E is a charge in respect of facilities afforded to and services undertaken on behalf of the ship- owner, master, agent by the Board in relation to the cargo which is under contract of carriage by them, in the same way as harbour dues.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e goods. The provision of there being a lien on the goods for the payment of the dues of the Board or the freight, make it clear that the Board did nu

arguments.claim: the liability to pay the charges- being for services rendered, the charges could be imposed only on the person to whom that service is rendered, that the entrustment of the goods to the Board is by the shipping agent though the entrustment is for ultimate delivery of the goods to the consignees and that the service is rendered to the shipping agent even though the consignee also benefits by that service

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions were disposed of by a learned Single judge of the High Court. He dismissed them holding that the liability to pay the charges.- being for services rendered, the charges could be imposed only on the person to whom that service is rendered, that the entrustment of the goods to the Board is by the shipping agent though the entrustment is for ultimate delivery of the goods to the consignees and that the service is rendered to the shipping agent even though the consignee also benefits by that service and it was not necessary for imposing the liability that the shipping agent must exclusively benefit from the service rendered.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ch. We therefore allow the appeals with companyts here and the Courts below, set aside the order of

arguments.claim: the Board had no authority to introduce the new scale E rates payable by the master, owner or agent of the vessel, -that the ship-owners liability ends when the goods had been put over the rail of the ship and from the moment the goods are put within the reach of the Board employees to take charge of them and tally clerk passes the receipt on behalf of the Board. The services in respect of which the new charges are sought to be levied cannot be deemed to be services rendered to the master, owner or agent of the vessel. They must be deemed to be services rendered to the consignee

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the appellate Bench reversed the order, allowed the petitions and issued a writ of mandamus as prayed. It held that the Board had no authority to introduce the new scale E rates payable by the master, owner or agent of the vessel, -that the ship-owners liability ends when the goods had been put over the rail of the ship and from the moment the goods are put within the reach of the Board employees to take charge of them and tally clerk passes the receipt on behalf of the Board. The services in respect of which the new charges are sought to be levied cannot be deemed to be services rendered to the master, owner or agent of the vessel. They must be deemed to be services rendered to the consignee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ch. We therefore allow the appeals with companyts here and the Courts below, set aside the order of

arguments.claim: the object behind the scale E rates is to expedite the discharge of the cargo at the quay and thus to enable a quantity of cargo to be discharged quickly. The services rendered, by the Board are therefore services to the ship and, consequently, charges for them are to be realised from the steamer-agents

the harbour dues are collected from the consignees as the Board is a bailee of the ship-owner who is a bailee of the shipper and who is bound by the contract to deliver the goods to the consignee or his nominee, on the presentation of the bill of lading
whatever services it performs at the time of the landing of the goods or on their removal thereafter, are services rendered to the ship

anchor.surface_text: whatever services it performs at the time of the landing of the goods or on their removal thereafter, are services rendered to the ship.

arguments.claim: when the Board takes charge of the goods from the ship-owner, the ship-owner is the bailor and the Board is the bailee, and the Boards responsibility for the goods thereafter is that of a bailee

anchor.surface_text: when the Board takes charge of the goods from the ship-owner, the ship-owner is the bailor and the Board is the bailee, and the Boards responsibility for the goods thereafter is that of a bailee.

arguments.claim: the charges for labour rendered idle are not in the nature of compensation or damages in respect of any loss, inconvenience or expenses caused to the Board or its shore-labour
the legal obligation of the master in respect of the unloading of the cargo continues beyond discharge from ship till delivery
Scale E rates made under s42 with sanction have force of law under s44, making steamer-agent liable is good law

anchor.surface_text: The question for determination, in the case, then is whether the law making the steamer-agent liable to pay these charges is good law.

holdings.text: The impugned charges were rightly levied by scale E on the master, owner or agent of the vessels and the Board could insist on the steamer-agent requisitioning the shore-labour to express an undertaking that he will pay the charges laid down in the Board's scale of rates in respect of labour rendered idle or not properly utilised and also for working more than one hook simultaneously at a vessel's hatch.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Board empowered under s.42 to frame scale of rates for services; sanctioned under s.44 with force of law; services under s.39 rendered to ship/owner upon request; charges for facilities/services to ship, not damages.

holdings.text: Whatever services [the Board] performs at the time of the landing of the goods or on their removal thereafter, are services rendered to the ship.

anchor.surface_text: whatever services it performs at the time of the landing of the goods or on their removal thereafter, are services rendered to the ship.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.39 empowers Board to provide services if required by owner (incl. agent); receipt under s.39(3) to ship-side; subsequent handling till delivery to consignee benefits ship-owner's obligation.

holdings.text: When the Board takes charge of the goods from the ship-owner, the ship-owner is the bailor and the Board is the bailee, and the Board's responsibility for the goods thereafter is that of a bailee.

anchor.surface_text: when the Board takes charge of the goods from the ship-owner, the ship-owner is the bailor and the Board is the bailee, and the Boards responsibility for the goods thereafter is that of a bailee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.40 explicitly makes Board bailee under Contract Act ss.151,152,161; delivery by ship-owner (bailor) for purpose of storage/delivery; not from consignee.

holdings.text: The Board takes charge of the goods on behalf of the ship-owner and not on behalf of the consignee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Receiving under s.39(1)(b) upon request by owner/agent; receipt absolves ship but Board not agent of consignee (no bill of lading presentation); lien under s.51 inconsistent with consignee agency.

holdings.text: The charges for labour rendered idle are not in the nature of compensation or damages in respect of any loss, inconvenience or expenses caused to the Board or its shore-labour.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Charges for services/facilities under s.42; labour engaged and paid idle time under piece-rate scheme; attributable to ship-side lapses; levied per sanctioned scale, not ex gratia damages.

holdings.text: The responsibility of the carrier for the goods does not cease merely by the technical discharge of the goods from the ship but continues up to their delivery in accordance with the terms of the bill of lading.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act: carriage till discharge, but delivery to entitled person per bill of lading; distinguishes cases on quay delivery; practice shifts responsibility to Board as sub-bailee.

holdings.text: The performance of services under s.39 is not obligatory on the Board but only if required by the owner.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the performance of any of the services mentioned in sub-s. 1 of s. 39 and the taking of charge of the goods are consequent on the Board being required to do so by the owner

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.39(1) empowers provision if required by owner (broadly defined s.5(7)); s.39(2),(3) conditional on request; steamer-agent practically requires as agent.

precedents.citation: Great Eastern Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Govindasamy 1 ... I.L.R. 1957 Mad. 840

anchor.surface_text: The case Great Eastern Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Govindasamy 1 , is number of much help. It was number disputed, in that case, that when, the master of the ship lands the goods and leaves them in charge of the Port Trust the legal effect is as if the master representing the shipping companypany has delivered the goods to the companysignee for whom the Port Trust must be deemed to be agents and that, having regard to the practice obtaining in the Madras Port, it was number necessary that there should be a formal requisition by the companysignee to the Port Trust to take charge of the goods. This case has number been taken rightly by the Court below to be of any direct authority on the question arising for decision in this case.

precedents.case_name: Great Eastern Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Govindasamy
precedents.cited_proposition: Delivery of goods by master of ship to Port Trust constitutes delivery to consignee, with Port Trust as agents of consignee; no formal requisition by consignee needed due to port practice

anchor.surface_text: We may number companysider some cases on which reliance is placed for the respondents. In Peterson v. Freebody Co. 1 , the facts were different from those of the present case. The Court was companysidering the liability of the companysignee for demurrage paid by the ship-owner, on account of the delay in the discharging of the cargo. The suit was between the ship owner and the companysignee. The charter-party provided The discharging to take place in eight days The cargo to be brought to and taken from alongside the ship at merchants risk and expense.

precedents.cited_proposition: Shipowner must place goods over the rail and in a position where consignee can take delivery; mere placing over rail insufficient; delivery requires action by both parties
precedents.cited_holding: If he merely puts the goods on the rail of his ship, he does number give delivery that is number enough... he must put the goods in such a position that the companysignee can take delivery of them.

precedents.citation: British Ship-owners Co. Limited v. Grimond 1 ... 1876 III Ses. Oases IV Series 968

anchor.surface_text: The case reported as British Ship-owners Co. Limited v. Grimond 1 , is again, number of help, as it simply held that delivery to the porters., whom the companysignee was obliged by the Harbour Regulation to employ and pay for the purpose of receiving, was delivery to the companysignee. In the present case there is numberhing to show that the companysignees are obliged by the Board to engage the shore-labour. Further, in the above case,

precedents.case_name: British Ship-owners Co. Limited v. Grimond
precedents.cited_proposition: Delivery to porters whom consignee is obliged by harbour regulations to employ constitutes delivery to consignee

precedents.citation: Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd. v. Rambler Cycle Co. Ltd., 1 ... l9591 A. C. 576, 586

anchor.surface_text: In Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd. v. Rambler Cycle Co. Ltd., 1  it was said It is perfectly clear. law that a ship-owner who delivers without production of the bill of lading does so at his peril. The Contract is to deliver, on production of the bill of lading, to the person entitled under the bill of lading The shipping companypany did number deliver the goods to any such person. They are therefore liable for breach of companytract unless there is some term in the bill of lading protecting them.

precedents.case_name: Sze Hai Tong Bank Ltd. v. Rambler Cycle Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Ship-owner who delivers goods without production of bill of lading does so at his peril and is liable for breach of contract unless protected by bill of lading terms
precedents.cited_holding: It is perfectly clear law that a ship-owner who delivers without production of the bill of lading does so at his peril.
